Bayesian inference in

Author

Marie-Hélène Burle

Published

February 25, 2025

Bayes’ theorem statistical inference probability distribution

Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC) No-U-Turn sampler (NUTS), a variant of HMC and Stan’s default MCMC engine

probabilistic programming language (PPL) explained simply in this (now outdated) blog post

On probabilities

Two interpretations

  • Frequentist
  • Bayesian

Frequentist

Frequentist approach to probabilities: assigns probabilities to the long-run frequency of events

For events for which there is no long-run, you imagine alternative realities and consider the frequency of occurrences in all those realities

The frequentist approach is computationally simpler and faster and returns summary statistics

Bayesian

Bayesian approach: assigns probabilities to our beliefs

It is a measure of believability in an event There is always some level of uncertainty

The belief is associated with the observer. Different people have different beliefs about the probability of an event occurring because they possess different information

This is the instinctive way to think about probabilities

The Bayesian approach is computationally more cumbersome and returns the probabilities of possible outcomes Only became possible with the advent of powerful computers and new algorithms such as Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC)

Which approach to choose?

As the number of instances of evidence N tends towards infinity, frequentist and Bayesian approaches tend to converge towards an objective truth

For small N, the inference is unstable and frequentist estimates have large variance and confidence intervals Bayesian approaches are more informative because they return probabilities

In short, the Bayesian approach is particularly useful for small data

Bayesian computing

Algorithms

HMC NUTS

Requires autodiff

Probabilistic Programming Language

Since the Bayesian approach is computationally intensive, the choice of framework, language, and compiler is important

First PPLs

WinBUGS replaced by OpenBUGS, written in Component Pascal, then JAGS, written in C++

Stan

Stan: a probabilistic programming language

but it is a domain-specific language which means that you have to learn the syntax to write a Stan script (that you can then call from R or Python via RStan and PyStan) PyMC: Python

Stan, see also website and paper brms in R doesn’t require learning Stan but only works for simple models

Stan has reverse-mode automatic differentiation

PPLs based on DL frameworks

Since HMC and NUTS require autodiff, many software have emerged in recent years, following the explosion of deep learning

(The Stan developers wrote their own autodiff system)

Pyro based on PyTorch

Edward, then Edward2 as well as TensorFlow Probability based on TensorFlow

Enters JAX

Had JAX existed when we started coding Stan in 2011, we would’ve used that rather than rolling our own autodiff system.

Bob Carpenter, one of Stan creators (https://statmodeling.stat.columbia.edu/2024/09/25/stan-faster-than-jax-on-cpu/)

JAX is designed natively for GPU coding and parallelism. Stan is not

What is JAX?

JAX is

See our introductory course and webinar

New backends using JAX

Edward2 and TensorFlow Probability can now use JAX as a backend

PyMC

PyMC is a PPL based on PyTensor. rely on building a static graph

pymc-extras is a testing ground for novel algorithms, distributions, and methods

NumPyro

NumPyro based on Pyro but uses NumPy and JAX

Blackjax

Not a PPL but a library of samplers
